section.title: &clm; Program Temporary Fix (PTF) Deployment
section.para: Occasionally, in order to fix a given issue, &suse; will provide a set of packages known as a Program Temporary Fix (PTF). Such a PTF is fully supported by SUSE until the Maintenance Update containing a permanent fix has been released via the regular Update repositories. Customers running PTF fixes will be notified through the related Service Request when a permanent patch for a PTF has been released.
Use the following steps to deploy a PTF:

step.para: When &suse; has developed a PTF, you will receive a URL for that PTF. It will contain the entire Python virtual environment (venv). You should download the packages from the location provided by &suse; Support to a temporary location on the &clm;. Set the variables for your Support ID and password. For example:
Remove any old data from the PTF repository, such as a listing for a PTF repository from a migration or when previous product patches were installed.
Move the packages from the temporary download location to the following directories on the CLM Server:

listitem.para: PTFs with noarch packages (*.noarch.rpm) go into /srv/www/suse-12.3/x86_64/repos/PTF/noarch/
PTFs with x86_64 packages (*.x86_64.rpm) go into /srv/www/suse-12.3/x86_64/repos/PTF/x86_64/

step.para: This example is for the &o_netw; venv, so that PTF is moved to the repo.
Create or update the repository metadata:
step.screen: &prompt.ardana;sudo /usr/local/sbin/createrepo-cloud-ptf Spawning worker 0 with 1 pkgs Workers Finished Saving Primary metadata Saving file lists metadata Saving other metadata

step.para: Refresh the PTF repository before installing package updates on the &clm;
step.screen: &prompt.ardana;sudo zypper refresh -fr PTF Forcing raw metadata refresh Retrieving repository 'PTF' metadata ..........................................[done] Forcing building of repository cache Building repository 'PTF' cache ..........................................[done] Specified repositories have been refreshed.

step.para: Running the ardana update playbook will distribute the PTF to the cloud server. Then you can find it loaded in the virtual environment directory with the other venvs.
The &compnode; before running the update playbook:
step.screen: &prompt.ardana;ls -la /opt/stack/venv total 24 drwxr-xr-x 9 root root 4096 Jul 18 15:47 neutron-20180718T154642Z drwxr-xr-x 9 root root 4096 Aug 14 16:13 neutron-20180814T161306Z drwxr-xr-x 10 root root 4096 May 28 09:30 nova-20180528T092954Z drwxr-xr-x 10 root root 4096 Aug 14 16:13 nova-20180814T161306Z
